response.answer_text: One of the most difficult things for people to understand, is the relationship between the music, what that piece of music does for the musician when they turn it into lyrics, to express, put in context, the music you just created. In other words, the song is cylindrical between music and lyrics, each affecting the other. Yoko had just made a short poem about how we Imagine. It takes this idea from her, to be applied possibly through John Lennon’s subconscious, to his playing about on the Piano. The Piano had taken over as the instrument to write songs from, because the guitar had become a trap for him to go into usual Chord Progressions, choice of Key, and melodic progressions. This is to avoid a massive problem most established musicians have, the tendency to make all your songs sounding the same. The Beatles production of a Song from whoever so ever created it, or even just a Song idea, is in my humble opinion, what made their songs so incredible. Firstly, “Fresh Ears” are totally important, because the creator can get too used to the song, too close, too objectively see what is wrong, or if there are ways to make it better. During Sgt Peppers this Paul McCartney overdubbing, because he could pop in living next door, was eroding this process of inclusion. “Well it’s MY SONG, I’ll decide”, was exactly what George Harrison said to Eric Clapton to enlist his help on While My Guitar Gently Weeps. This territorial attitude developed, which was a stupid self-destruction of the ways that had made them successful. VERY STUPID. Firstly, the repeated three note Chord that is the heart of the Song, is NO CHORD! It is NOT anywhere in any Piano Chord Book. Obviously reading musicians say this is not true, and will go a million times around the houses, to prove it. What they don’t prove, is WHY JOHN LENNON JUST DID IT! These educated idiots, are unable to write extortionary songs themselves, they are just smart arses about how it was done. John Lennon just put the little poem Yoko wrote, to the Metre (Beat and Timing), to this repeated Chord, with a Beat of Silence, a little Riff, to go back to the same Chord. It goes around and around, slowly building up to the breakout from this Repeated Pattern, to an increase of Tempo and Volume. Then John has got the music, the structure to make more of, plus that idea of what the Song is ALL about. Not bad for a musical genius, who says he knows nothing about music! As for the important meanings from the lyrics. In my head, John is saying, why argue, promote religion, a spiritual journey is possible if we don’t fight over these issues. Just Imagine they didn’t exist, so we cannot fight and kill each other over these issues, of Religion, Possessions, Materialism, and Nationality. He knows what people will say: “John Lennon is a Dreamer, not in any reality”, well he defeats that too, by inviting you to be a Dreamer too, and join him. The Music and Lyrics match perfectly, adding force to both. The Major = equals Happy Mood, and the Minor = equals Sad, is also defeated as always, as Imagine goes into more subtle thoughts and feelings. The Hall Mark of The Beatles is their ability to write a Sad Song with the sounds of Hope included, no better achieved than in this song Imagine. The meaning is very similar to Hey Jude, that life can BE great, even going through life’s hardships. With Imagine, John Lennon is saying WE as people, are making these Hardships, why NOT invest in them? BE FREE OF THEM. Well, will we?

This song from John Lennon seemed to resonate with millions of people across the universe. I know that many consider Imagine his very best work, it has a simplicity and earnest power that cuts through obscurity, it presents I guess a spiritual perspective that is totally without any religious affiliation-and this baffles some. John Lennon was what we used to call a ‘free thinker’, this means that he assumed the right to build his own conclusions about life, society, politics. He certainly explored some spiritual movements, notably the Transcendental Meditation approach of a Guru of the day, but he wound up rejecting this as a way of life, taking from it some valuable insights. John Lennon was not a devotee of any religious movement, but he was certainly a spiritual person, an observer and thinker. The seeming ambiguity of a song that speaks of ‘Peace, ‘No Possessions’very much in the Buddhist vein, but also he spoke of ‘No Religion Too’ creates cognitive dissonance in some people. He asked us to imagine a world where humanity accepted one another, where we renounce material gain, religious conflicts, war, and accepted that we all follow our own journey. On the surface, Imagine can come across as being almost a ‘Kumbyah’ anthem, a hippy-dippy peace/love/understanding type song, it is very much more than this, in my opinion. To our cynical eyes & ears in 2018, Imagine can look and sound a little trite. For me, the song explores some very ancient ideas. These ideas are old, but perennial because they point to a possible ideal for humanity. Just imagine, Lennon asks us, if everyone decided to simply stop being hostile, stopped striving to force one another to think a certain way, to believe certain things, and to simply ‘Be’. Like all ideals, it is open to derision, accusations of naivety, simplistic thinking; this is why the song is called ‘Imagine’, just for one minute, John Lennon asks us, allow these ideas to actually take form in your mind. The simple piano music, with that recurring theme supports the quiet simplicity and frank expression of the ideas. Among all of the people who keep striving to push others down, to compete, to displace, to build their vision of what the world should be there is a growing number each generation of people who want none of this, who are working towards peace, acceptance, living in harmony. “You may say I am a dreamer, but I’m not the only one, I hope one day you will join us, and the world will live as one.” John is speaking to this group, who can hear him, and those who maybe are moving towards this, and hoping you will join us. It is a dream, an imagined wonderful potential.

"Imagine" is a song about communism since John Lennon described it as "virtually the Communist Manifesto" when it was released. In general, communism advocates the absence of class divisions within a community. Nonetheless, communism is an umbrella term which encompasses various categories under the branch. For instance, Marxism, Maoism, Leninism, et cetera. Among all the subcategories under communism, I firmly believe that Leninism fit in the context of "imagine." Leninism falls under communism, which was the official state ideology of the parties of the Communist International in the Soviet Union (USSR). The purpose behind Leninism is to achieve a revolutionary transformation of the capitalist state into a proletariat-led state. John Lennon had indulged himself into the writing of the song since the early 1970s when capitalist ideologies started to emerge. Therefore, components of communism are expressed in a mild and obscure way to avoid direct clashes with the rival school of thoughts. In "Imagine there's no heaven" and "No hell below us," John used insinuation to introduce the idea of Marxist-Leninism. With "Heaven" and "hell" representing the affluent class and grass-root class, respectively, it shows the presence of a hierarchy in the society. As John called upon his fellow to "imagine" a situation without the division of "heaven" and "hell," it eventually means the most idealistic society is a society without hierarchy and class struggles. Marxist-Leninism also advocates shared property within society. This idea has embedded in lyrics like "Imagine no possessions," "no need for greed or hunger." In these two lines, John used euphemism to omit the origin of "possessions," "greed" and "hunger" and left a blank space for publics to reflect, not only on capitalism but also themselves. Back in the days in the military, my fellows and I always played this song and sang it next to the majestic Laptev Sea. Although we came from different families, we shared the same blood, values, and properties. I believe this is "the brotherhood of man."

Imagine, just look up the word in The Merriam Webster Dictionary. You Get the following definition: imagine verb imag·​ine | \ i-ˈma-jən \ imagined; imagining\ i-​ˈmaj-​niŋ , -​ˈma-​jə-​ \ Definition of imagine transitive verb 1: to form a mental image of (something not present) imagine accidents at every turn 2: SUPPOSE, GUESSI imagine it will rain 3: to form a notion of without sufficient basis : FANCYimagines himself to be a charming conversationalist 4archaic : PLAN, SCHEME intransitive verb 1: to use the imagination 2: BELIEVE sense 3 What is the John Lennon song “Imagine” about? John Lennon correctly used the word “imagine” as a transitive verb. With number 1: to form a mental image of (something not present). His way to describe his idea of Imagine: Imagine there’s no heaven, it’s easy if you try, no hell below us, above us only sky. So to effectively analyze this simple sentence, the author is asking his audience to “imagine” by forming this mental image of what would it be like if we imagined there’s no heaven, or hell. Whether or not if every person on the earth believes if there is a heaven or hell doesn’t matter, what matters is let’s all just draw up a mental picture of what it would be like if there was no such place as either one. ”Imagine” is about envisioning a world without any strife or friction, by not separating people by what religion they are, and if they believe in heaven or hell. Or whether they are rich or poor, “Imagine no possessions, it’s easy if you try.” The key word here is to “envision” it. What many people get confused is when the author says no heaven, no hell, no countries, and no possessions. They have bleeped out the key word: Imagine. Imagining it and realizing it are two different things. They are polar opposites of one another. So when he tells us to “Imagine” the things that he mentions, what he does mean is that these things are not real, just an image. That is what “Imagine” is about. Reference Definition of IMAGINE

Per Wikipedia:  In a 1980 interview with David Sheff for Playboy magazine, Lennon remarks on the message of "Imagine":  Sheff: On a new album, you close with "Hard Times Are Over (For a While)". Why?  Lennon: It's not a new message: "Give Peace a Chance" — we're not being unreasonable. Just saying "give it a chance." With "Imagine" we're asking, "can you imagine a world without countries or religions?" It's the same message over and over. And it's positive.  Ono indicated that the lyrical content of "Imagine" was "just what John believed — that we are all one country, one world, one people. He wanted to get that idea out." In addition, the content of "Imagine" was inspiration for the concept of Nutopia: The Country of Peace, created in 1973. Lennon included a symbolically mute "anthem" to this country on his album Mind Games. Also, inspiration for Yoko's Imagine Peace Tower in Iceland came from words in the second verse: Imagine all the people living life in peace.  In the book Lennon in America, by Geoffrey Giuliano, Lennon commented that Imagine was an "anti-religious, anti-nationalistic, anti-conventional, anti-capitalistic [song], but because it's sugar-coated, it's accepted." http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imagine_(song)

“Imagine” was John Lennon’s utopian dream. He imagined a world without fear, war, greed, hunger or hatred. He wanted unity, brotherhood and shared wealth. He asked listeners to imagine a world in which the things that divide us no loner existed: heaven and hell, national borders, religion, and material possessions. “Imagine” is an atheistic, anti-religious and anti-capitalist statement.
